attributes.comment:
To Whom It May Concern;

I writing to ask that the proposed fee increase to the Immigration and
Naturalization Benefit Application and Petition Fee Schedule not be increased. I
am currently waiting to be matched with an orphan child from China. Given the
current waiting period and the gradual increase in time that has been evidenced
over the past 6 months, it is quite likely that I will be waiting for at least two years,
if not three. Given the fact that necessary documents are only valid for a short
time, it is likely that I will have to pay fees to renew these documents at least
once, if not twice. Additionally, I will be required to re-submit fingerprints, with the
excessive fee, each time.

This will be my only child. I am not a wealthy person, but I do have enough to give
a healthy and secure home to a child. I wish that could be a child from the United
States, but the costs are prohibitive to the extreme. In fact, I chose China
because of it's affordability (vs. the US) and it's reliability (vs. the US). It is
unfortunate that I will be required to wait for such a long time, but it is the situation
I must accept.

Each time I pay the USCIS fees, it decreases the amount of time I will be able to
spend with my child, because I will have return to work more quickly after arriving
home and take on more jobs to make up for it. Additionally, as a teacher, my
fingerprints are already on file with the FBI. In fact, having worked with children for
the past 20 years, my fingerprints have been taken more than 9 times. The USCIS
is the only agency to charge such an exorbitant rate for a seemly simple
procedure. Why are these fingerprints are not accessed when the renewal comes
up? These would seem an easier and less work intensive procedure.

I realize that many are concerned about false identities and immigrations issues.
However, penalizing adoptive parents is not the answer. There seems to be a
myth that those choosing to adopt from outside of the US are wealthy "yuppies"
looking for perfect babies. This is an aggregious stereotype and simply not true.
However, these fee increases will certainly limit adoptions to those types of
families as they will have to consider adding yet another $1000 to amount required
to process the adoption.

Please reconsider these fee increases.

Sincerely,

Jana Johnson
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Jana Johnson
